subtitle: becoming a sniper was my long cherished
dream
since childhood in fact
and even now i can recall in my new
details scenes from the pre-war film
sniper
it was about the feats of a super
accurate russian marksman in the first
world war in particular i vividly
remember the scenes from the film
dealing with the art of camouflage by
making a replica of a tree stump or a
dead horse and planting it in no man's

and hit the enemy accurately from there
i want through my narrative to open up
one more page in the history of the
great war for the fatherland
to describe how the snipers movement was
born and grew to mass proportions in
leningrad and played a huge role in the
positional trench warfare around the
besieged city
our academy commenced regular classes
from morning till night the cadets
strove to acquire as quickly as possible
all the tricks of the sniper's art which
lieutenant baturin willingly shared with
us
and so we set off to take the
examination it was a gloomy october
morning the trenches had long been
permeated with damp and the cold at
night had become more noticeable the
first significant amount of snow had
fallen the previous day straight onto
the dry frozen ground like a blanket
covering the crippled earth of leningrad
we all realized that our first wartime
winter would be very severe

my partner was ivan dobrik a sturdy lad
of short stature with a broad
good-natured face with a perpetual sly
expression on it
he was an excellent marksman on the
smallest targets and a downright
outstanding serviceman
a column of smoke from the stoves of the
nazi dugouts was rising high into the
frosty sky and steam was pouring out of

hungry as we were it seemed to us that
the germans were being fed right round

through the telescopic sights of our

of their defenses and german soldiers
large as life both groups and
individuals occasionally wandering here
and there unfortunately beyond the range
of our bullets
we lay like that for a long time without
taking a single shot nestled up against
the snow-covered parapet and closely
pressed against each other lying in the
frost for several hours on end without
moving was not much fun and we were not
used to it the frost went right through
us we so wanted to get up and warm our
frozen feet and hands with some vigorous

we were in a lousy mood
it began to get dark
suddenly i noticed some moving targets

ivan take a look i can see some nazis on

completely forgetting that i was only

i'll take the last one then the first

don't let them get away evgeny
making the usual adjustments to allow

the sound of a sniper's bullet is not

i barely caught the sound of my short my

it seemed to me i saw the last of the

the other two continued on their way
without noticing what had happened
cheered by my success i decided to shoot
the second nazi
the second conqueror also fell as if he

i had more than enough time to reload

it made a sharp crack as if a woodpecker

and felled by my bullet
the third nazi collapsed dead on top of

a sniper has many enemies especially in
the summer apart from the main one the
enemy there are others from whom you can
never know what to expect they can be
bees wasps flies ants and even field
mice i remember once on a fine summer's
day ivan dobrik and i were lying in
ambush
we had to lie out in no man's land in
thick grass in a flat open area almost
right under the enemy's noses
we conducted observations of the german
front line and the approaches to it
having correctly calculated that in
thick grass in a flat field without a
single landmark it would be difficult
for the nazis to spot us we would have
laned there calmly till darkness fell
but for pure chance
my partner lying motionless in the
baking sun suddenly became an object of
interest to a tiny field mouse
how this curious daredevil got past his
tightly fastened belt into ivan's tunic
i still cannot understand while the
mouse was crawling around somewhere on
his back i even managed to put up with
it being afraid to move
but when it ventured lower down onto his

patience snapped he suddenly bellowed

began laughing hysterically
i was seriously afraid he had discarded
his rifle and was rolling around on the
grass and yelling with a heart-rending
voice what's up ivan are you out of your
mind there are germans right next to us
they'll spray us any minute now i said
in bewilderment the whole situation and
the expression on ivan's face as he
continued to roll around in the grass
put me in a foolishly merry mood
i too began to laugh
of course the nazis were not slow to
open fire with mortars
let's run for it ivan could barely utter
the words through tears of laughter and
grabbing his rifle he darted towards our
trenches pressing one hand to a wound
he'd only just suffered as he went
you've put on quite a show said the
observer escorting ivan and me
undercover have you turned into a couple
of halfwits or what
the constant bombing raids the
continuous artillery fire the pursuit of
enemy snipers the possibility that any
second you could become a target
yourself for an equally experienced
german marksman or perish from a stray

fragment all made for constant tension
at night when we were off duty i used to

vlad and i had no trouble finding things
to talk about by the light of a homemade
oil lamp fueled by low-grade petrol or
fat we would recall the distant and
precious days of peacetime and of course
we recalled our hometown of tambov our
traumatically short youth our home
kith
and kin
one time we became so involved in our
conversation that dawn had already
broken beyond the dugout's closed door
we were reminded of it by our regimental

bursting into the dugout kazirav shouted
at us from the doorway his eyes sticking
out of his head
what are you sitting there for gambling
nonsense when the nazis have played such
a filthy trick on us what sort of trick
asked dude in irritation expecting as
usual from kazarev another prank or

us what are you gonna do we got to the
front line and indeed on top of a german
dugout stood a plywood sign on narrow
poles thrust into the snow
inscribed on it with charcoal and big

to our side in ungrammatical russian

it is no secret that the casual slack

they didn't need to worry it wasn't them

looks like that's the headquarters i

i set my sights at 700 meters and loaded

the bullet left a clear trace in the

one of the other men turned looked at

they both stood there and looked at the

then realizing what was up they started

i didn't allow them to ponder for too

i focused on the rider who had leaned

it's all over the thought race through

december was a harsh month
the winter of 1941 to 1942 has remained
in everyone's memory it came early and
it was ferocious
the winter months became a difficult
test for both of us the defenders of
leningrad and for its residents
unsettled by their heavy losses the
german command was compelled to call in
troops urgently from other fronts and
direct their super sharp shooters
against leningrad
so aces like this expert masters of
their craft killers with seniority and
huge experience appeared in our area too
we quickly felt the presence of these
nazi snipers they would fire through the
slit of a pillbox and skillfully take
out our observers
i resolved to test myself against one of
the nazi ace snipers who had appeared in
our sector by tracking the path of the
nazi's shots back to their point of
origin i came to the conclusion that he
was sitting somewhere close to the tram
lines in the broad expanse in front of
our third platoon to the right of it and
closer to the gulf of finland
in no man's land
and so clad in a snow white camouflage
smock over my regular clothes i crawled
in that direction one dark and frosty
night
by first light i was already lying in no
man's land well camouflaged in the deep
snow
i was not concerned about concealment
but when i succeed in spotting the enemy
he would also be camouflaged against the

was

however

beside this little spot on the surface a

in white camouflage
in a trace it crept up a couple of

from the unexpected nature of it all and

i didn't even manage a shot
they literally carried me in their arms

oh dear
